title: What will the Bureau of Labor Statistics report the U.S. civilian unemployment rate (U3) to be for the month of December 2018?
preds: Updated for trend, may have confused in some local knowledge.
Labour market has been very stable over the past 12 months, unlikely to move. Question oddly has 3.7, 3.8, 3.9 lumped together.

See rates pretty steady in December seasonally adjusted. A smaller chance of lower rate given number of job openings and potential fills with Dec graduates, although except for seasonal, not many employers hire during December. Unsure how Govt shutdown gets included.
Rebalancing slightly on the basis of this excellent discussion: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/799238

https://tradingeconomics.com/united-states/civilian-unemployment-rate-percent-m-sa-fed-data.html 3.7% last 3 months with downwards trend in general this year (down 0.4 in 12 months: 0.03 a month) so lets say expected is 3.67% add normal distribution: its moved a total of 0.8 (sum(abs(jumps)) this year so lets say 0.8/12=0.0666.. is standard dev. 
also consider that values are rounded so "between 3.7 and 3.9 inclusive" is really "between 3.65 and 3.95 inclusive" etc
inside between 3.4 and 3.5 inclusive:
3.35-3.55 is: -0.32 to -0.12 /0.066666 = -4.8 to -1.8 standard devs
inside more than 3.5 but less than 3.7:
3.55-3.65 is: -0.12 to -0.02 / 0.066666 = -1.8 to -0.3 standard devs
inside between 3.7 and 3.9 inclusive:
3.65-3.95 is: -0.02 to 0.28 / 0.066666 = -0.3 to 4.2 standard devs by normal distribution calculator (http://onlinestatbook.com/2/calculators/normal_dist.html): 
3.35 to 3.55 is worth: 0.036
3.55 to 3.65 is worth: 0.346
3.65 to 3.95 is worth: 0.618 rounding for this sites accuracy already gives 101%... hope for the best
Based on economic trends and seasonality.
Nov unemployment is at 3.7%. Jitters entering the market and trade tensions with China may induce a higher unemployment rate.
Recent seasonal patterns, but also factoring in a slightly worsening economic outlook that might show an early impact.
December employment should remain relatively steady with a possible slight drop in the unemployment number due to an already tight labor market and slightly increased demand for seasonal labor.

Turmoil in the White house will contribute to lower consumer spending during the holidays and thus fewer temporary workers in retail and entertainment employment.   Concern about a possible government shutdown and a rapidly declining stock market will cause many businesses to put off hiring decisions until 2019.
Right on the 3.7 line, and lots of noise in the data

Unemployment has been dropping and I have not seen many indications that the trend may reverse. Additionally, from a political standpoint, Trump is under pressure and this would be a big win for him so he may pressure the bureau
BLS reported 3.7% in November.  Oil at under $50 per barrel may cause layoffs.
My thinking has improved further, once again based on this discussion: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/799180
I hadn't noticed before but we seem very close to tipping into 3.6 as discussed here https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/799180. Hat tip to @Khalid.
Already reach the top of employment and now is in a down trend.
Employment is in a down trend, labor markets remain tight.
In New Mexico, oil patch raiders are recruiting right off of construction sites. For a $2/hr raise, many men are dropping their tools on the spot and going off with the raiders.
4.0% doesn't seem likely without some added disruption.
New hiring of permanent employees grinds down a lot this time of year, and only resumes on 1/1, though that number is likely to be swung by investment expectations.

3.3% or lower
3.4% to 3.5%
3.6%

Think we should see under the 3.7% that has been consistent over the last 3 months. Just based on the fact that given the December holidays, most companies will hold of hiring until after new year's day.  Any seasonal holiday hiring is typically captured in November (thx giving/black friday) or does not fall under U3 given that seasonal employees plan for holidays and come off previous contracts and are not captured with U3 metric.

I quickly looked at the trends between November and December from 1998 to 2017 (https://www.bls.gov/opub/ted/2018/u-3-unemployment-rate-was-4-1-percent-in-december-2017-u-6-was-8-1-percent.htm?view_full) and used them as probabilities with the value for November 2018 (https://www.bls.gov/news.release/empsit.t15.htm).

Adjusting to say it's now more likely the U3 hits 3.6% in December. Most recent statement by BLS said we added 155,000 jobs in November, but rate stayed at 3.7%. (https://www.bls.gov/news.release/pdf/empsit.pdf) By my calculations (admittedly rough), about 160k jobs = .01%. That would mean December needs to net just ~5-6k jobs to tick this down to 3.6%. I think that is very likely given last minute flexible holiday hiring in several industries. If my math is bad, this prediction will be bad, but if it's close, the odds of tipping into the lower bracket will be good.
Unemployment is quite low already. Am I anchoring by saying it can't go much lower? It's also possible it could just as easily be 3.6 or 3.8.
Unemployment has recently been quite low. I think the holidays will max the decrease.
Base only based on historical moves delta's 2000-2018 excluding 2008/2009

Last November the civilian unemployment rate was 3.7% and in the last couple of years it was flat between sep to jan. Going down one tenth on 2016 and going down a bit on 2015 as well. The hard question is deciding how much it will change from 3.7. I'm inclined to believe that the general trend is down, and the employment growth trend set by Obama seems to be holding for this administration as well.

https://tradingeconomics.com/united-states/civilian-unemployment-rate-percent-m-sa-fed-data.html    3.7% last 3 months with downwards trend in general this year (down 0.4 in 12 months: 0.03 a month) so lets say expected is 3.67% add normal distribution: its moved a total of 0.8 (sum(abs(jumps)) this year so lets say 0.8/12=0.0666.. is standard dev.
3.5-3.67 is 0.17/0.0666~ 2.55 standard devs from mean going down
3.67-3.7 is 0.03/0.0666~ 0.45 standard devs from mean going up
3.7-3.9 is a *further* 3 standard devs going up by normal distribution calculator (http://onlinestatbook.com/2/calculators/normal_dist.html):
3.5-3.67 is worth: 0.4946 (-2.55 to 0 standard devs)
3.67-3.7 is worth: 0.1736 (0 to 0.45 standard devs)
3.7-3.9 is worth:  0.3261 (0.45 to 3.45 standard devs) summing gives:
0.6682 for 3.5-3.7
0.3261 for 3.7-3.9 rounding for this sites accuracy gives: 67% 3.5-3.7, 33% 3.7-3.9 and no point to calculating others because that's already 100% when rounding to nearest integer so they're gonna get rounded to 0 anyway
With U3 already at 3.6 and Xmas employment, should drop lower, especially with"Individual-1" counting.

Current unemployment rate is around 3.7% which is the lowest in years. With seasonal workforce and hires it has a good possibility of going down another .1%, but the expectation amongst most estimates is that the rate is as low as it ever will get. Many analysts are projecting an upturn based on the Chinese trade issues, increasing price on commodities, and a shift to the economy. https://www.bls.gov/charts/employment-situation/civilian-unemployment-rate.htm shows the recent trends. Unemployment situation is explained at https://www.bls.gov/news.release/empsit.nr0.htm.

Given the previous mentioned conditions, I don't see any reason for the next rate to have a large swing from the base reference rate, which is 3.7% in this case.
base rate seems to be the current rate, and I just adjusted the possibilities around that base rate

November’s forecast was 3.7%.  There should be more seasonal employment in the month of December, however, there has been a pick up of layoff announcements as well.  The likelihood is the unemployment rate will remain unchanged.

3.7 is considered full employment, there are factors that will not allow much more reduction regardless of how jobs are available. We have a segment of the population that is not interested or qualified for positions available.

Updating because you get a slightly different answer if you just look at November to December changes. So, weighting my previous forecast as 2 and the Nov to Dec U3≤5.5 as 1 (due to small sample size), I get these new percentages.

Updating because I finally looked at the distributions of monthly changes going back to 1948. Then looked at changes when unemployment was less than or equal to 5.5, 4.5, and 4.0%. The distributions were pretty similar in all cases. The main difference being that the lower the unemployment, the greater chance of no change. My forecast reflects the U3 ≤ 4.0% distribution.

There is usually a decrease at year-end. FED has been very slow in increasing rates and POTUS has accelerated the market. This may actually result in an inflationary spiral soon. It can't go more than 0.1-0.2%, hence, it will most probably fall between 3.5-3.7%.
Tax cuts increase employing power for firms. Protectionist policies also help ‘bring’ jobs back from abroad. Boon to employment. Should be very low indeed.
Things are getting worse, but this percentage changes slowly and minimally.
More people will reenter the workforce.

Updating because November data got added. Difference between Dec and Nov was +-0.2 in the last 8 out of 10 years, and since this isn't a particular crisis or recovery year I think the other two years can be regarded as outliers. No change, +0.1% and +0.2% was the difference for 5/8 years, so 63% for 3.7 to 3.9 inclusive buckets. The same method would give 13% for more than 3.5/less than 3.7 and 25% for 3.4/3.5, but I inverted this because I think gradual change is more likely than more radical change here, plus the U3 has not been 3.5% or lower in any month in the last 10 years reported in the link in the question.

Updating now that November's numbers are out. I may update again if I can come up with a statistical way of looking at it. For now this is just responding to the recent flatness of the U3 rate.

I used the data from https://data.bls.gov/pdq/SurveyOutputServlet and looked at months in the last 20 years where the unemployment rate was below 5% and looked at how many times it stayed the same, increased by 0.1, increased by 0.2, increased by 0.3, decreased by 0.1, decreased by 0.2, decreased by 0.3, and decreased by 0.4. I then took the ratio of these occurrences over total months to get my estimates.
Compare the current rate and the change over months in previous years

The chances of December 2018 delivering record low unemployment figures is unlikely. Recent developments such as the volatility (and drop) in the stock market, the ongoing trade war with China, and the closure of GM plants both informs my belief that U3 will not drop below 3.7%. The downward trend of U3 since October 2010 will unlikely be affected, at least significantly, by recent, current, and ongoing developments until at least the first or second quarter, and even then, given the remarkable resilience of the US labour market despite the tumultuous geopolitical and economic climate. Finally, the fall and holiday season in the US will help maintain U3 if not push it slightly lower given seasonal consumption patterns. As such, I believe that U3 will remain below 4% and possibly even dip lower than the 3.7% of September and October 2018. Nonetheless, I have attributed small percentages to U3 both exceeding 4% as well as falling below 3.5% in the event of unforeseen circumstances and the recent volatility in the stock market, as well as the possibility that domestic firms are more confident in their economic outlook than the market suggests.
I don't think employment will change much in the time frame of the question.

I am basing these probabilities on the Bureau of Labor Statistics from October 2018 and the Dow Jones Industrial Average losses since October. According to MSNBC's Market Watch, the DJIA have erased all gains for 2018 since October. Reference link: https://www.bls.gov/news.release/pdf/empsit.pdf. 2nd Reference Link: https://www.cnbc.com/2018/11/20/stock-market-dow-futures-negative-as-tech-stocks-sink.html. Seasonal hiring will be lower this year due to online purchasing and investor confidence is sinking given current market trends.

Despite the fact that Christmas is a busy period in retail the trend of shopping online has created a challenging environment for traditional retailers and the long term view is for retail jobs to grow by just 2% by 2026. https://www.bls.gov/ooh/sales/retail-sales-workers.htm
With the percentage below 4 now, the increased hiring for the holidays will lower it further.

The BLS unemployment rate from 1998-2017 overwhelming shows either an equal or lesser from October of the respective year to the following December. This is the platform I have chosen to base my model. The few exceptions either included national security unease* (2001 terrorist attacks) and the recent market crash (bls reported it as impacting Dec 2007-Jun 2009; source: https://www.bls.gov/spotlight/2012/recession/pdf/recession_bls_spotlight.pdf )
     *There is a personal assumption being made that the timeline between the terrorist attack and the subsequent invasion of Iraq had an impact on these numbers. This is a strong assumption, but I feel that the effects have a strong correlation. That said, given my (imperfect) model the vast majority of outcomes over the selected timeframe show that  unemployment will either stay the same OR drop by 0.1%. Since the questions split these two outcomes into two separate options, they will collectively consume the highest percentage (~2/3) of likeliness to occur. I would even venture to say that if the middle option included both 3.7 and 3.6, my forecast would be even more weighted in it's favor to occur (75-80%). This is because we don't appear to be in the midst of any distinct economic booms, and we also don't have any distinct detractors (i.e. major wars, or recessions) If the November Unemployment rate from BLS shows an increase, my figures will significantly shift away from the middle option ("More than 3.5% but less than 3.7%") onto the next option down ("Between 3.7% and 3.9%, inclusive"). If there is a decrease, my forecast will only be significantly changed if it drops to 3.4% or below for November.  Cheers!

Recent bear market on Tech Stocks - any layoffs that the companies may plan to increase their earnings will not yet take effect by December 2018 (the companies would have seen the fallout coming though before the market and have probably taken action already - there are frequent layoffs before Christmas - but I still think the bear market is too recent for an effect to be felt before December 2018). 
2. The effect of people hanging onto their jobs to earn bonuses in December or Q1-19 was considered but most employed people will be leaving for another job which will not affect the employment figures.
3. People seeking work may drop over the festive season - which would decrease the unemployment figures.
4. Black Friday and Pre-Christmas spending - without any looming interest rate hikes would mean more people in employment - even if temporarily - and will further decrease the unemployment stats.

Thanks to GJO admins for clearing this for me. As per the FAQ, "the precision of our threshold will match the source’s precision". Since BLS only reports the first decimal, the 3.5-3.7 bucket is effectively 3.55 to 3.64. The 3.7 to 3.9 (inclusive) bucket covers 3.65 to 3.94.

Unemployment stats are well below long-term averages (say 5%, depending on time-scale). Unemployment is at a 49-year low, so there is pressure back to the mean. Offsetting is a seasonal drop in December (an average drop of about 0.1% over the last few years, when the rate was almost double the current rate)
This forecast approximates a normal distribution, mean of 3.7, and 90% or so of probability falling between the values 3.5 to 3.9

Trend is down since 2008. Data does not appear to have a strong seasonality component where December is significantly above or below November or January. This is a little surprising as you'd expect seasonal December employment but I trust eyeballing the data more than my guess about seasonal employment. Maybe seasonal employment balances winter construction slowdown? Most recent BLS estimate is October, which was 3.7%. Initial prior estimate is 3.7%. Tends to move in 1.5 percentage point increments. Suggests a range between 3.5% - 3.9% (1 SD) or 3.3% - 4.1% (2 SDs) if normal. The Fed has been raising rates since late 2016. IR changes may take 18 mos - 2 yrs to take effect. Would expect to see an uptick in the unemployment when rates "hit" the economy.  Trump admin has placed tariffs on a number of imports. Tariffs are due to rise in January. This may stimulate activity through December as importers & exporters rush to beat tariffs.  No sign of gov't fiscal cliff through December. On balance, tilt estimate to lower side.
We are at full employment, so the unemployment rate can't go much lower. Housing has also started to backpedal, so construction etc. jobs will level off if not reverse.

Job gains have been strong, and the unemployment rate remained at 3.9% in August, with non-farm payrolls edging up. In addition, total industrial production saw solid growth in July and August. However, with labor market conditions already tight, there is little room for the employment to have significant gains by December 2018.

Over the trailing 5 years, the December unemployment rate has been less than or equal to the October rate. In cases when it is lower, it is often lower by maximum 0.2%. Given the trade situation with China and recent market volatility, I expect it to be equal to the October rate this year. Since the October rate was 3.7%, a breakpoint in the answer buckets presented here, I expect both surrounding buckets to be highly likely with the inclusive bucket more probable than the less than bucket.  https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/UNRATE/

Could go to 3.6, but more than a tenth point move is unlikely. There are some crazy forecasts on this question. Look at the time series data. We have been in a many year steady decline. Since 2010 the monthly rate changes have averaged -.03, three hundredths of a point. There are November and December reports to come. Based on the mean, our expectation should be about -.06 from the 3.7 we are at now. But opinion seems to be we are at full employment and the rate can not go much lower. Less than 3.4 meaning 3.3, would be a .4 decline, nearly impossible. 4% or more, a 3 tenths increase also just about impossible

Following the trends of recent years, the unemployment rate typically stays level for the month of December. And logically, I can think of a number of factors that would lead to a decrease in labor movement during the month: - Employees not wanting to alter their income during the holidays
- Employees wanting to stay for year end and holiday bonuses
- Employees wanting to wait until "next year" for large life changes
- Employers not wanting to try to find new staff during holiday months and/or during year end processes

As a base, I examined the last five years of data and noticed 2 month moving avg change had a std. dev. of 17 bps. This puts me squarely in the 3.5% - 3.9% range for the majority of my probability. Additional I examined the month of Dec change from Oct for the last 20 years and noticed that only 5 times has there been unemployment below 4.5% and it has either had a (10 bps) change or no change. Further, when examining all data back to 1948 there have been 10 instances of UE at or below 4.0% with on two instance of an increase to unemployment and two of no change. Additionally, examining midterm election years, appears there is no significant impact to the change in unemployment patterns v. non midterm years, at a high level.
Even in the toughest economic years, the unemployment rate goes down a bit in December. If the rate exceeds 4.0 this December then something is a-brewing.

Unemployment rate in October was 3.7%. Barring a major disruption, the rate should be within +/-20 bps of this range, with a slightly higher probability of further tightening given the recent trend.

U3 typically stays constant or dips slightly from the November rate during December due to seasonal holiday hires.  Barring a calamity it is unlikely the rate would rise during the holiday season. That said there is always the chance that something out of the ordinary could cause the rate to rise or dip and I think that a 1 in 20 chance of a big spike or dip is within reason (natural disaster, unexpected consumer product that spikes demand, whatever)

Highest probability of econometric time series is equal to or very close to most recent data point.  Base rate is 3.7 with equal probability estimates assigned to 3.6 and 3.8.  Each of these was estimated to be 20% probability so I estimated 60% probability of 3.6, 3.7, or 3.8.  Because one outcome also includes 3.9, I added 10 percentage points and thus 50%.  Next lower outcome is 20% because of equal estimate among 3.6, 3.7, or 3.8.  Outcome could surprise to downside because of seasonal strength, thus higher weighting to 3.4 and 3.5 versus 4.0.

Labor reports the number to the tenth of a percent so "More than 3.5% but less than 3.7%" is really only 3.6%. "Between 3.7% and 3.9%, inclusive" has three possibilities 3.7 (the current figure) 3.8 & 3.9. Since this is inclusive of the current number and a regression to the mean, it contains the highest probability.

The unemployment rate has had an annualized standard deviation of 9.4% over the past 12 months and with two months left that would mean the standard dev. over the next two months would be 3.85% (assuming normal distribution, which it obviously has a downward trend). 1 SD (3.55% - 3.84%), 2 SD (3.41%, 3.98%), 3 SD (3.27%, 4.12%). Lowest point was 2.5% all time. It is hard to tell, but the real drivers are the labor force population and the unemployed population, labor force participation is stabilizing, but I am concerned about the asymptotic relationship with unemployed rate.
Rate is unlikely to move significantly in the next two months.
I expect civilian unemployment to remain about the same as it is, hiring is still strong, but as rates rise this may slow.

BLS data, including in the link in the question, only goes to 1 decimal point. The "official rate" goes to 1 decimal point only. I've never seen unemployment described beyond 1 decimal point. So then, aren't many responses overweighting the probability of "More than 3.5% but less than 3.7%" since that really just means 3.6%? Compare that to "Between 3.7% and 3.9%, inclusive" which represents 3.7, 3.8, and 3.9. Part of the point of these forecasting competitions is that better forecasters think hard about how things are measured and don't just replace this question with the question "Will unemployment go up or down for the rest of 2018?" Happy to be steered back if I can get clarification that actually this question will use 2 decimal places. Otherwise, while I think 3.6% is a distinct possibility, my forecast is as I've laid out here.

Although hard to compare numbers from older years, since we don't know how the methodology differed exactly, but if you see what the lowest U3 rate has been in the past - In 1953, it was 2.5% at one point. I'll use that to conclude that it can go further lower than current 3.7%(in other words, the frictional unemployment is lower than this). Now, if you look at the difference between Dec & Oct rates historically, i think it makes sense to only consider last few years since they are quite similar in terms of economic improvement. In most of those years, Dec is less than Oct by 0.1, a few more than that, and two of them the same. Using this data, and assuming nothing drastic changes, i'll put it at almost a coin flip above and below 3.7%, slightly tilted downwards.
